title: Richard Tait, Co-Inventor of the Board Game Cranium, Dies at 58

content: Richard Tait, an entrepreneur, business executive and venture capitalist who helped invent the board game Cranium, a familiar part of American family life in the late 1990s and 2000s, died on July 25 at his home in Bainbridge Island, Wash. He was 58.

title: Will an Investigation of a Former Mexican President Lead to Charges?
description: After years of promises, many Mexicans fear that the announcement of a corruption probe into Enrique Peña Nieto might be nothing more than a political tactic.
content: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican attorney general’s office said this week that it was investigating former president Enrique Peña Nieto for money laundering and illicit enrichment, the first official confirmation of such a probe by federal prosecutors.

content: TOPEKA, Kan. — Lines of Kansas voters, resolute in the August sun and 100-degree heat, stretched beyond the doors of polling sites and wrapped around buildings on Tuesday to cast ballots in a primary election. A few suffered heat exhaustion. Firefighters passed out bottles of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: With Climate Deal in Sight, Democrats Turn Hopes on Sinema
description: Now that Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia is on board, the Arizona Democrat has emerged as the final holdout on Democrats’ domestic agenda. So far, she’s staying characteristically silent.
content: WASHINGTON — As Senator Kyrsten Sinema, Democrat of Arizona, took her turn presiding over the Senate floor on Tuesday, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a fellow Democrat, got down on one knee beside her at the dais, leaning in intently to speak to her in hushed tones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Lucid Motors slashes production forecast, blaming supply chain chaos.
description: The maker of luxury electric cars that hopes to challenge Tesla struggled to get parts and build vehicles in the second quarter.
content: Lucid Motors, a maker of widely praised electric cars that the company has struggled to mass-produce, cut its production target for the year by almost half on Wednesday after delivering just 679 vehicles in the second quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gates
title: When White People Become People of Color
description: In Mohsin Hamid’s new novel, “The Last White Man,” the white protagonist awakes to find he has turned brown.
content: The opening sentence of “The Last White Man,” the latest novel by the Pakistani writer Mohsin Hamid, may sound overfamiliar — “One morning Anders, a white man, woke up to find he had turned a deep and undeniable brown” — but who wouldn’t read on? A protagonist as erudite as his creator might have been grateful not to turn into a giant bug; Anders, who works in a gym and seems as aliterate as he is inarticulate, feels only rage at losing his whiteness: “He wanted to kill the colored man who confronted him here in his home, to extinguish the life animating this other’s body, to leave nothing standing but himself, as he was before.” But the self-divided Anders — could he have a more Nordic name? — calms down when he learns there’s a pandemic of changelings; the formerly white come to include his yoga-teacher girlfriend, Oona; Oona’s racist mother; and, eventually, everybody who was born white. (All except Anders’s dying father, a secondary character who gives the book its catchy, if misleading, title.) By the end, a pulp-magazine premise has metamorphosed into a vision of humanity unvexed by racial animosities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Shutting the Door on the Hard-Knock Life
description: The requirements of the theater, and the constant physical and emotional risks facing performers, have many demanding their basic needs as humans.
content: Getting to play Cinderella in a Broadway revival of “Into the Woods” sounds like a young musical theater performer’s dream, until you break your neck doing the pratfalls built into the role.

content: This summer marks 15 years since Apple released the first iPhone, and since then, smartphones have become the Swiss Army knives of technology. But with the avalanche of updates since 2007, less-obvious features are often buried in the process. Here’s a quick look at some possibly overlooked tools, shown here in iOS 15 and Android 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Kenya’s Elite Talk About American Power in the Past Tense
description: At a garden party I attended in a wealthy Nairobi suburb, the guests talked global politics and the upcoming presidential election in Kenya.
content: NAIROBI — A Kenyan friend of mine who graduated from Harvard Business School recently told me that the United States is a good place to get an education, but “it is no longer a leading light.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: George Bartenieff, Fixture of Downtown Theater, Dies at 89

content: George Bartenieff, an actor and producer who was a significant figure in the Off Off Broadway and experimental theater world as a founder of two theater groups, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 89.

title: Barrington Stage Company Names Alan Paul as Artistic Director
description: The nonprofit helped make the Berkshires a destination for culture lovers under Julianne Boyd, who is retiring.
content: The Barrington Stage Company announced Wednesday that Alan Paul, the associate artistic director of the Shakespeare Theater Company in Washington, will become its new artistic director, taking over the nonprofit theater company in Western Massachusetts known for producing notable new musicals and popular revivals and helping turn the Berkshires into a cultural oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello and Marcus J. Moore
title: Five Minutes That Will Make You Love Duke Ellington
description: We asked jazz musicians, writers and others to tell us what moves them. Listen to their choices.
content: A few years ago, Zachary Woolfe, a New York Times critic and editor, posed a question: What are the five minutes or so that you would play for a friend to convince them to fall in love with classical music? How about Mozart? Or the violin? Or opera?
source.name: The New York Times

content: Well, it’s officially sticky season.

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: The Pedal Steel Gets Its Resurrection
description: As the sound of country music has shifted, the emotive whir of its classic instrument has often been sidelined. The complicated antique has found new life in surprising forms.
content: When DaShawn Hickman was 4 years old, living just 32 steps from the tiny granite House of God church in Mount Airy, N.C., he picked up a lap steel his uncle had built for his mother. Stretching the electric guitar across his tiny knees for the first time, using a D-cell battery as his slide, he traced the hymns his mother sang.

content: In 2019, the White House declared that phone and internet equipment from Chinese technology companies should be ripped from every corner of the U.S. because it posed an unacceptable risk of snooping or sabotage by the Chinese government.

content: LOS ANGELES — In 2014, during “After the Final Rose,” a live TV special that followed “The Bachelorette” finale, the season’s runner-up Nick Viall turned to the bachelorette, Andi Dorfman, and said: “If you weren’t in love with me, I’m just not sure why you made love with me?”

content: WASHINGTON — The buzz and clatter of baseball’s annual trading deadline drew most of the attention around the sport on Tuesday, and rightly so. title: I Was a Lesbian Until This Summer. What Happened?

I hung out with an amazing woman last year. But I met a guy at my internship this summer. Over a month, we became good friends, then we started a romantic relationship. content: California this week became the latest state to step up its response to monkeypox, with Gov. Gavin Newsom declaring a state of emergency on Monday because of the growing outbreak.

title: Nadler and Maloney Are Collegial at Debate. Their Rival Is Combative.

content: WASHINGTON — Determined to prevent a repeat of the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol, backers of an overhaul of the federal law governing the count of presidential electoral ballots pressed lawmakers on Wednesday to repair the flaws that President Donald J. Trump and his allies tried to exploit to reverse the 2020 results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Nancy Pelosi meets with Taiwan’s president.
content: Nancy Pelosi met with Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan’s president, after visiting Taiwan’s Legislature earlier today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Has Big Plans for 2025, and He Doesn’t Care Whether You Think He’ll Win
description: Ignore them at your peril.
content: As he contemplates a third straight run for the presidency, Donald Trump has a multimillion-dollar political machine and a network of tax-exempt advocacy groups at his disposal. He also has a plan. The plan is to wrest control of the federal government from what he sees as a policy apparatus dominated by “radical left-wing Democrats.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Adler-Bell
title: The Violent Fantasies of Blake Masters
description: His bizarre, menacing vision for American politics could well define the future of his party.
content: Blake Masters’s first campaign ad opens with a shot of the Sonoran Desert. A plaintive piano theme tinkles as Mr. Masters, a 35-year-old venture capitalist and, as of early Wednesday morning, the Republican nominee for Senate in Arizona, delivers a monologue in voice-over. “The truth is, we can’t take America for granted,” he says. “And if we want to keep it, we’ve got to fight for it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Julie Benko Was the ‘Funny Girl’ No One Had Heard of, Until Now
description: The actress, who covered for Beanie Feldstein, gets the part to herself for the next month, and Broadway fans are thrilled for her.
content: Early on in the musical “Funny Girl,” a young and determined Fanny Brice sings a line that anyone even slightly acquainted with the show will be familiar with: “I’m … (deedle-dee deedle-dee) the greatest star … (deedle-dee deedle-dee).”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Michael Corkery
title: Walmart Will Cut 200 Corporate Jobs
description: The move comes a week after the company announced it was lowering its profit forecast as inflation was catching up with consumer spending.
content: Walmart is laying off 200 corporate workers, a person briefed on the matter confirmed on Wednesday, one week after the company slashed its profit outlook saying inflation was pressuring customers to make fewer purchases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Results from primaries in Arizona, Michigan, Kansas, Missouri and Washington.
description: Kansans defeated a constitutional amendment that would have enabled abortion restrictions, Missouri Republicans breathed a sigh of relief over their Senate nominee, and more results.
content: Voters in five states with major primary contests went to the polls on Tuesday. Here’s a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Needs Minority Rule
description: Both democracy and choice triumph in Kansas.
content: One side effect of Roe v. Wade was that it allowed the anti-abortion movement to pretend to be on the side of democracy. True, the decision was popular, and majorities since the 1970s have wanted to see abortion legal in at least some circumstances. But Roe prevented duly elected state governments from passing abortion restrictions that were in some cases also popular with their constituents. The goal of the anti-abortion movement was and remains national prohibition. Its language called for returning the matter to the state voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden and Michael Levenson
title: Girl, 12, Escapes Captivity, Leading Alabama Authorities to Find 2 Bodies
description: José Paulino Pascual-Reyes, 37, was charged with capital murder and first-degree kidnapping after the authorities said they found two decomposing bodies inside his house.
content: A 12-year-old girl who had been held captive in a home in rural Alabama was found walking along a nearby road on Monday, which led the authorities to the bodies of her mother and brother inside the residence, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Chris Buckley
title: Welcomed by Taiwan, Pelosi Leaves Rising Tensions With China in Her Wake
description: In a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Ms. Pelosi offered assurances of American support. Taiwan now faces the prospect of Chinese military drills that could violate what it says are its territorial waters.
content: After weeks of silence ahead of a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was anything but understated on Wednesday during a day of high-profile meetings in which she offered support for Taiwan and irked China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How New Yorkers Push the Limits
description: From speed zones to traffic crossings to parking rules, city residents try to get away with going a little faster, or cutting it close, or being a little later.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll take a quick look at limits — speed limits and time limits — prompted by the expanded operation of speed cameras in the city. We’ll also look at a book that’s finally permitted to be read in the place it’s about, except for two pages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ferren
title: Golden Sand, Calm Waters and Dramatic Dunes: 5 Family Beaches in Europe
description: From the calm, clear waters of Ålbæk, Denmark, to the soft, sandy shores of Spain’s Balearic Islands, a selection of favorite beaches that both children and their parents will love.
content: What makes a great family beach? Clean water for swimming, clean sand for sitting, sunning, playing or walking, and naturally occurring amusements like gullies, tide pools or rocks for climbing. Access to decent food and bathrooms and even showers are also a plus and, thankfully, relatively common in Europe, where I’m based. And, of course, stunning scenery and nearby towns with lots of activities certainly help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in England: Rural Splendor in the South West Region
description: The pandemic has ‘accelerated the market in Somerset exponentially,’ with domestic buyers and investors keeping inventory scarce.
content: Built on the footprint of a former agricultural building, this 4,170-square-foot contemporary house sits on four acres in Binegar, a tiny village in the Mendip Hills, five miles east of the cathedral city of Wells in England’s South West region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Mickelson and Other LIV Golfers File Antitrust Suit Against PGA Tour
description: A complaint filed on behalf of 11 players pushed back against the punishments imposed by the PGA Tour for players who participate in events sponsored by the upstart LIV series.
content: Eleven golfers affiliated with the breakaway LIV Golf series have filed an antitrust lawsuit against the PGA Tour, challenging its suspensions and other restrictive measures used to punish those who signed on to play in the Saudi-backed LIV events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Vecsey
title: With Scully in the Booth, California Baseball Took Root
description: The Dodgers’ move to Los Angeles was made seamless by a man who never said too much and was perfect for his new surroundings. His old surroundings still miss him.
content: At the end of the 1957 baseball season, Brooklyn Dodgers management packed up for a long-threatened move across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Black Grace Dances Out a Different Kind of Buzz
description: This New Zealand company returns to the Joyce Theater with two New York premieres, but neither are as penetrating as “Handgame,” a vintage gem.
content: I was expecting an energy boost, and then some. But Black Grace, a celebrated company from New Zealand known for dazzling, fast dancing, returned to the Joyce Theater with “a different kind of buzz,” as the Lorde song “Royals,” quoted in the first dance of the evening, puts it. Was it contemplative? Was it intimate? In any event, for much of the program, modern dance struggled to hold its own against traditional movement drawn from the South Pacific. And vice versa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Christiaan Triebert, Kamila Hrabchuk and Stanislav Kozliuk
title: Ukraine Builds a Case That Killing of P.O.W.s Was a Russian War Crime
description: At a Russian-held prison, graves were dug days before the explosion that killed at least 50 Ukrainian troops held there, Ukrainian officials said.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — Five days after an explosion at a Russian prison camp killed at least 50 Ukrainian prisoners of war, evidence about what happened remains sparse, but Ukrainian officials said on Wednesday that they were steadily compiling proof that the mass slaughter was a war crime committed by Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Vin Scully, Voice of the Dodgers for 67 Years, Dies at 94
description: The team has had many great players since World War II, but it was Mr. Scully, a gifted storyteller and a master of the graceful phrase, who became the enduring face of the franchise.
content: Vin Scully, who was celebrated for his mastery of the graceful phrase and his gift for storytelling during the 67 summers he served as the announcer for Dodgers baseball games, first in Brooklyn and then in Los Angeles, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Lauren Fox and Elizabeth Dias
title: In Kansas, Support for Abortion Rights Didn’t Just Come From the Usual Places
description: Rural Republicans joined suburban Democrats to create huge turnout and a broad coalition that voted to preserve abortion rights by a fat margin.
content: PRAIRIE VILLAGE, Kan. — DeAnn Hupe Seib is a fiscally conservative, churchgoing Republican from rural Kansas. When faced with a ballot question about whether abortion rights ought to be removed from her state’s constitution, she voted no. So did her home, Jefferson County, which favored Donald J. Trump by a 32-point margin in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Has the War in Ukraine Affected You Economically?
description: Tell us your story.
content: Many of us are feeling economic pain right now, with inflation eating away at how much we can buy and a slowdown in the market eroding our savings. The war in Ukraine has only exacerbated our financial issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: OPEC Plus members agree to a small increase in oil production.
description: Politically, the paltry increase would appear to be a snub of President Biden, who went to Saudi Arabia seeking assurances from big producers that they would act to cool oil markets.
content: The group of oil producers known as OPEC Plus approved a small increase in production on Wednesday, just over two weeks after President Biden visited Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to seek assurances that the group would act to cool oil markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Switzerland, a leader in gold refining, bans Russian gold imports.
description: The move follows similar bans by the European Union and the United States.
content: Switzerland on Wednesday banned imports of Russian gold and gold products, on the heels of similar moves by the European Union and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Shane Goldmacher
title: ‘Your Bedroom Is on the Ballot’: How Democrats See Abortion Politics After Kansas
description: After a broad victory in a deep-red state, Democrats are vowing to elevate the fight over abortion rights in midterm races across the country.
content: A decisive vote to defend abortion rights in deeply conservative Kansas reverberated across the midterm campaign landscape on Wednesday, galvanizing Democrats and underscoring for Republicans the risks of overreaching on one of the most emotionally charged matters in American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Pelosi’s widely watched flight to Taipei took a circuitous route. Here’s why.
description: Nearly three million people logged onto their computers to try to track Nancy Pelosi’s controversial trip to Taiwan. As it took a different and more circuitous path, many were confused.
content: Nancy Pelosi’s plane departing Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, for Taipei on Tuesday evening was one of the most closely tracked flights of all time. It was also unusually circuitous, taking a three-hour detour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Barcelona Spent Its Way Into Crisis. Can It Now Spend Its Way Out?
description: One of the world’s biggest soccer teams needed to close a $700 million shortfall. Its president, Joan Laporta, may have done it. But the club’s problems are not over.
content: Joan Laporta’s smile was hard to miss. Staring down from a vast digital billboard last month, the grinning image of the president of the Spanish soccer giant F.C. Barcelona covered almost an entire side of the Palms Casino Resort in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: The Coming Battle for the South
description: Russia appears to be massing troops near Kherson, where Ukraine has been planning a counteroffensive.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina, Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: In 4 Swing States, G.O.P. Election Deniers Could Oversee Voting
description: Arizona and Michigan have joined Pennsylvania and Nevada in elevating Republican candidates for governor and secretary of state who reject the 2020 outcome and might do the same for future elections.
content: PHOENIX — With Tuesday’s primary victories in Arizona and Michigan added to those in Nevada and Pennsylvania, Republicans who have disputed the legitimacy of the 2020 presidential election and who could affect the outcome of the next one are on a path toward winning decisive control over how elections are run in several battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Could I Forgive Him One Last Time?
description: When her ex-husband became terminally ill, she had a difficult choice to make. Over a decade later, her decision still resonates.
content: When Victoria Rosner was seven months pregnant, her husband filed for divorce. He “decided that he couldn’t be married anymore, not to me, he said, and probably not to anyone,” Victoria wrote in her Modern Love essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Theater at Geffen Hall to Be Named for Two Key Donors
description: The Wu Tsai Theater will honor a $50 million gift from Joseph Tsai, a founder of the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, and Clara Wu Tsai, a philanthropist.
content: In late 2020, as coronavirus infections surged and cultural institutions shuttered, the fate of the long-delayed renovation of David Geffen Hall, the home of the New York Philharmonic, was uncertain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: One Eric Reaps in Missouri as Another Eric Sows
description: Schmitt, having reinvented himself as a hard-line culture warrior, can now revel in his Senate nomination, while Greitens has met what appears to be a humiliating political end.
content: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo. — Voters here in this languid town along the Mississippi River, famous for being the boyhood home of Rush Limbaugh and for its history of devastating floods, sent an unmistakable message on Tuesday: They like Eric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why You Should Try Crevice Gardening: ‘This Is the Future’
description: In a world where water is increasingly scarce, these rock gardens are not only pretty, but surprisingly resilient.
content: What’s a crevice garden? It’s a rock garden taken right to the edge — an extreme design inspired by dramatic, impossible places like alpine ridges, windswept seacoasts and sun-baked deserts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: How ‘The Bear’ Captures the Panic of Modern Work
description: You don’t have to work in a kitchen to recognize the chaos and precarity the show depicts.
content: The Original Beef of Chicagoland is the fitting name of the restaurant at the heart of the acclaimed FX series “The Bear,” which stars Jeremy Allen White as Carmy, a world-class chef who returns home to run his family’s sandwich shop after his older brother’s suicide. Of all American cities, Chicago is the one whose mythos is most closely associated with a particular kind of work: honest, meaty, broad-shouldered labor that forges you into something bigger, nobler. Like the city it’s set in, the restaurant in “The Bear” is an unpretentious place, humbly catering to “the working man.” But “the working man,” we soon learn — as a young, Black, female sous-chef mocks an older, white, male manager’s use of the label — is a contested term, especially in an environment where nobody does anything but work, and pretty much nobody has anything to show for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.9 Million Homes in Connecticut, Washington and Colorado
description: A 1732 Colonial in East Haddam, a Tudor Revival house in Seattle and an 1893 Italianate home in Denver.
content: This house sits on a wooded road not far from Gillette Castle State Park, where the main attraction is a medieval-style house built in the early 20th century by the actor William Gillette, surrounded by walking trails and picnic areas. The Hadlyme Ferry Boat Launch, the departure point for ferries crossing the Connecticut River into the town of Chester, is half a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Grace Ashford
title: Adams Won’t Let Up on Bail Reform, Putting Pressure on Hochul
description: Mayor Eric Adams is calling forcefully for another round of changes to state bail law, putting pressure on Gov. Kathy Hochul as she runs for a full term in November.
content: Hours before Mayor Eric Adams held a news conference on Wednesday to argue that an “insane, broken system” allowed repeat offenders to keep getting arrested and then released without bail in New York City, Gov. Kathy Hochul issued something of a pre-emptive strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Cynical Low for the Democratic Party
description: Selling out democratic principles is not the way for Democrats to hold on to their slim House majority.
content: On the anniversary of the Jan. 6 attacks at the U.S. Capitol, Roy Cooper, the governor of North Carolina, took to Twitter not just to condemn that day’s violence but also to warn that the dark forces behind it were still very much alive and still a threat to the future of American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: What’s God Got to Do With It? The Rise of Christian Nationalism in American Politics.
description: Esau McCaulley and Katherine Stewart on how the G.O.P. weaponized Christianity — and where we go from here.
content: Christian nationalism has been empowered in American politics since the rise of Donald Trump. From “Stop the Steal” to the storming of the U.S. Capitol and now, the overturn of Roe v. Wade — Christian nationalist rhetoric has undergirded it all. But given that a majority of Americans identify as Christian, faith also isn’t going anywhere in our politics. So what would a better relationship between church and state look like?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network and C. Ross Flatt
title: 8 Webinars on How to Teach Writing With The New York Times
description: Our collection of previously recorded writing webinars explores how to teach the kinds of real-world writing found in newspapers, including editorials, reviews, profiles, personal narratives and more.
content: Are you looking for engaging ways to teach your students about how to share their stories? Are you thinking about bringing a real-world approach to your writing curriculum for the next school year? Have you thought about incorporating multimedia projects, such as podcasts or photography, into your classroom but don’t know where to start?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: It’s Been a ‘Summer of Disasters,’ and It’s Only Half Over
description: Are we prepared for the climate-related calamities that come next?
content: “We’re naming summer ‘Danger Season’ in the U.S.,” wrote Kristy Dahl, the principal climate scientist for the Union of Concerned Scientists, in early June. A couple of days later, at Axios, the climate reporter Andrew Freedman echoed that warning: “America is staring down a summer of disasters.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Jennette McCurdy Is Ready to Move Forward, and to Look Back
description: In her memoir, “I’m Glad My Mom Died,” McCurdy, best known for her role in“iCarly,” reflects on her time as a child actor and on her troubled relationship with her mother.
content: When Jennette McCurdy was 16, she was in her third year on “iCarly,” the hit teen sitcom on Nickelodeon. Millions of young viewers admired her for her comic portrayal of Sam Puckett, the wisecracking pal of its title character, and she was proud that her lucrative work was helping to support her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: A Creamy, Spicy Dip Unlike Any Other
description: The Houston chef Dawn Burrell brings her biography to everything she cooks, like her creamed collard greens spiked with chile sauce.
content: Dawn Burrell couldn’t be busier. When we spoke several weeks ago, the chef was in the midst of planning a Juneteenth event, preparing for the opening of a restaurant in Houston and organizing her many advocacy projects — but this workload, it seems, was a regular day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Amy Qin
title: As China Plans Drills Circling Taiwan, U.S. Officials Fear a Squeeze Play
description: Administration officials say they are hoping China’s military exercises last only a few days, but they are discussing their options if the movements expand into something more.
content: WASHINGTON — For years the deliberate “strategic ambiguity” in Washington’s China policy has left unclear how the United States would respond to a full-scale, amphibious invasion of Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger
title: Taiwan and Ukraine: Two crises, 5,000 miles apart, are linked in complex ways.
description: The fear since the start of the war in Ukraine has been that Moscow and Beijing will be driven closer as the United States casts both issues as a struggle between authoritarianism and democracy.
content: Hours before Russia began its invasion of Ukraine in late February, the Chinese Foreign Ministry issued a statement that was clear, stern and not really about Russia or Ukraine at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A ‘Reversible’ Form of Death? Scientists Revive Cells in Dead Pigs’ Organs.
description: Researchers who previously revived some brain cells in dead pigs succeeded in repeating the process in more organs.
content: The pigs had been lying dead in the lab for an hour — no blood was circulating in their bodies, their hearts were still, their brain waves flat. Then a group of Yale scientists pumped a custom-made solution into the dead pigs’ bodies with a device similar to a heart-lung machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times Reports a Gain of 180,000 Digital Subscribers
description: Revenue from digital advertising fell slightly in the second quarter, but subscription revenue continued to rise sharply, the company said.
content: The New York Times Company added about 180,000 net digital-only subscribers in the second quarter of the year but generated less digital advertising revenue, it said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and David F. Gallagher
title: Taking Stock of Pelosi’s Taiwan Trip
description: More fallout may be ahead for businesses and investors from a visit that tested China’s appetite for confrontation.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi left Taiwan today after a short visit that could have major repercussions. It drew unusual support from Republicans, condemnation from Beijing and quiet defiance from her hosts in the face of Chinese threats. But China experts predict more fallout may be ahead for businesses and investors from a trip that tested China’s appetite for confrontation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: ‘I Want You to Hear This’: A Sandy Hook Mother Confronts Alex Jones
description: Scarlett Lewis, whose son Jesse, 6, was killed in the elementary school shooting, rebuked the Infowars fabulist over his lies in a face-to-face courtroom confrontation.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — For 90 searing minutes in a courtroom on Tuesday, a Sandy Hook mother brought the conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones face-to-face with the havoc she said his lies about the mass shooting that killed her son had wrought on her family and on the national discourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: It’s Destiny!
description: Take a pop quiz with Daniel Bodily’s puzzle.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hoo boy, I have a feeling today’s puzzle is going to be a challenging one for solvers. I’ll keep this preamble short and sweet, but just know that if you had a tough time on this tricky puzzle by Daniel Bodily (his solo debut), you’re not alone. Mr. Bodily has collaborated on two New York Times crosswords in 2022, and with today’s puzzle he demonstrates his solo constructing chops and his creativity. I expect we’ll see plenty more good stuff from him in the future. It’s his destiny!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Tudor Dixon Came From Back in the Pack to Become the G.O.P. Nominee for Michigan Governor
description: Now comes the hard part, expanding beyond her conservative base to defeat Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.
content: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich. — Tudor Dixon, a former conservative media personality, just pulled off a feat that might have seemed impossible a few months ago, catapulting over her better known competitors in a crowded and chaotic primary to win the Republican nomination for governor in Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: A ‘Whisper’ Leads a Real Estate Reporter to Claims of Deed Theft
description: In an interview, Stefanos Chen, who covers tenants, owners and buildings in New York, discussed a recent investigation and his approach to the beat.
content: Last week, The New York Times published a front-page article by Stefanos Chen, Ted Clifford and Camellia Burris that examined a history of questionable dealings behind a New York real estate empire. Sanford Solny, who owns small residential buildings across the city, is accused by prosecutors of deed theft, a practice used to swindle homeowners out of their properties while leaving them stuck with the mortgage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Joseph Goldstein
title: U.S. Could Have Had Many More Doses of Monkeypox Vaccine This Year
description: The Department of Health and Human Services delayed asking the manufacturer to process the bulk vaccine the government already owned into vials.
content: WASHINGTON — The shortage of vaccines to combat a fast-growing monkeypox outbreak was caused in part because the Department of Health and Human Services failed early on to ask that bulk stocks of the vaccine it already owned be bottled for distribution, according to multiple administration officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Tudor Dixon, a conservative commentator, will challenge Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in Michigan.
description: Ms. Dixon, who was backed by former President Donald J. Trump and Michigan’s powerful DeVos family, topped a field of relatively unknown Republican candidates.
content: Tudor Dixon, a conservative media personality with the political backing of Michigan’s powerful DeVos family, won the state’s Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Appeals Deshaun Watson’s Six-Game Suspension
description: The league notified the players’ union that it would appeal an arbitrator’s decision and seek an indefinite suspension. Commissioner Roger Goodell or his appointee will hear the appeal.
content: The N.F.L. appealed the six-game suspension of Cleveland Browns quarterback Deshaun Watson on Wednesday, according to a league spokesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu
title: Pelosi draws crowds as she moves through Taiwan’s capital.
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As Speaker Nancy Pelosi moved around Taiwan’s capital with her entourage on Wednesday, taking one meeting after another, the people of Taiwan shadowed her nearly every step of the way.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As Speaker Nancy Pelosi moved around Taiwan’s capital with her entourage on Wednesday, taking one meeting after another, the people of Taiwan shadowed her nearly every step of the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat, Rachel Bovard and Tim Miller
title: Is It All About ‘Fealty to Trump’s Delusions’? Three Writers Talk About Where the G.O.P. Is Headed
description: How should we assess the Republican Party?
content: Ross Douthat, a Times Opinion columnist, hosted an online conversation with Rachel Bovard, the policy director at the Conservative Partnership Institute, and Tim Miller, the author of “Why We Did It: A Travelogue From the Republican Road to Hell,” about the recent primaries in Arizona, Michigan and beyond, and the strength of Donald Trump’s hold on the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Weighs In on the Killing of Ayman al-Zawahri
description: Noah argued that safe houses should be called something different because “every terrorist gets killed in a safe house.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: Why So Many Cars Have Rats in Them Now
description: Driving in the city is on the rise, but if New Yorkers think they can avoid rats this way, they are in for quite the surprise.
content: For eight years, Libby Denault had taken her Prius to the same auto body shop in Brooklyn for tuneups and other repairs, which it always handled expeditiously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Monkeypox, Explained
description: It’s not Covid, but there are good reasons to take precautions.
content: The viral disease monkeypox is spreading around the world. So far, there are more than 6,300 known cases in the U.S., almost entirely among gay and bisexual men. New York, California, Illinois and some cities have declared states of emergency, following the World Health Organization’s own declaration of a global emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Justice Dept. Subpoenas Pat Cipollone, Trump White House Counsel
description: Mr. Cipollone is the highest-ranking White House official in the lead-up to Jan. 6 who is known to have been called to testify by federal investigators.
content: Pat A. Cipollone, the White House counsel under former President Donald J. Trump who tried to stop some of his more extreme efforts to overturn the 2020 election, has been subpoenaed by a federal grand jury investigating activities in the lead-up to the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, a person familiar with the subpoena said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany to Gazprom: Your Turbine Is Ready, Let Us Deliver It
description: Olaf Scholz showed off a refurbished turbine for the Nord Stream 1 pipeline that Russia has said is the reason it can’t send more gas to Germany.
content: Standing before a hulking metal turbine that normally propels natural gas from Russia to Germany through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany rejected Russia’s contention that technical problems were behind the sharp curtailment in gas flows to Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Election Victories by Trump Allies Showcase His Grip on the G.O.P. Base
description: Tuesday’s primaries in Arizona and Michigan gave the former president a slew of symbolic triumphs.
content: PHOENIX — Primary victories in Arizona and Michigan for allies of Donald J. Trump on Tuesday reaffirmed his continued influence over the Republican Party, as the former president has sought to cleanse the party of his critics, install loyalists in key swing-state offices and scare off potential 2024 rivals with a show of brute political force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Rzewski for Lovers? A Pianist Mines a Prickly Modernist’s Gentler Side
description: When Lisa Moore turned 60 her husband commissioned a Rzewski score for her. Now, she has recorded a Rzewski album, showcasing a wide range of emotion.
content: The renowned composer and pianist Frederic Rzewski, who died last year, was celebrated for the committed nature of his leftist politics as well as his music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Ridgewood, Queens: A Multiethnic Area That’s ‘Like a Whirlpool’
description: The constantly changing neighborhood may share a border with Bushwick, Brooklyn, but residents want you to know ‘you’re in Queens, bro.’
content: For Bikash Kharel, who runs a Nepali restaurant in Ridgewood, Queens, called While in Kathmandu, almost every night is cause for a geography lesson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Zorich
title: A Battlefield From 1777 Yields a Dozen Mercenaries’ Remains
description: Archaeologists uncovered the remains of 13 Hessian soldiers killed by American forces in the bloody Battle of Red Bank near Philadelphia.
content: Archaeologists working at Red Bank Battlefield, a site along the Delaware River south of Philadelphia, have uncovered the remains of 13 Hessian mercenaries who were killed during a bloody Revolutionary War battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Sommer
title: In the Late ’70s, Teen Punks Ruled New York. These Are Their Stories.
description: High school students spent their nights forging a colorful late-night scene marked by big choruses and few rules. The bands didn’t last, but the taste of art and freedom shaped their lives.
content: The year was 1977, and the first generation of New York City punk and alternative bands had moved on to larger venues and the international touring circuit. The thrash of hardcore was still a few years down the pike. Yet the storied music venues of Manhattan were alive and aloud with excited, underage patrons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: If These Beautiful Ornaments Could Speak
description: A wide-ranging show at the Drawing Center takes on frills, arabesques and the complicated legacies of cultural appropriation.
content: “The Clamor of Ornament,” a dazzling new exhibition at the Drawing Center, gathers nearly 200 drawings, etchings, photographs, tunics and weavings to tell a complicated story, one that spans five centuries, about cultural exchange and appropriation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Nicole Sperling
title: Neon, Film Distributor of Indie Darlings Like ‘Parasite,’ Ponders Sale
description: It has tapped the investment bank Raine to assess its options, on the heels of a megadeal for another independent distributor, A24.
content: Neon, the independent distributor behind Academy Award-winning films such as “Parasite” and “I, Tonya,” has tapped the merchant bank Raine to explore a sale of some or all of its business, according to three people familiar with the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: What puts someone at risk of catching monkeypox?
description: Here is what experts say about how the virus is transmitted during everyday interactions — and which behaviors carry the most risk.
content: As monkeypox spreads across the United States, it may be giving people flashbacks to the days of wiping down counters and groceries to get rid of the coronavirus. But for most people, the risk of getting monkeypox remains low. Almost all cases in the current outbreak — 98 percent — have been in adult men who have sex with men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Democrat Seeks Inspector General Inquiry Into Pentagon’s Missing Jan. 6 Texts
description: Messages from the phones of top Trump administration officials at the Defense Department who were involved in the response to the Capitol riot appear to have been erased.
content: WASHINGTON — The No. 2 Senate Democrat on Wednesday called for an inspector general investigation into missing text messages from top Defense Department officials in the Trump administration related to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Yes, Kansas Is Conservative. It’s Also Complicated.
description: The state’s politics have never been as simple as the common narrative conveys. Tuesday’s vote on an abortion amendment is an example of its unpredictability.
content: In the popular imagination, Kansas is synonymous with modern American conservatism, and not without reason. It has voted Republican in every presidential election for more than 50 years and hasn’t elected a Democrat to the Senate since 1932.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Nina Feldman, Rachel Quester, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Why Democrats Are Bankrolling Far-Right Candidates
description: Some of the party’s campaign partners have employed a contentious strategy in the buildup to the midterms.
content: Democrats are meddling in Republican primaries this year to an unusual degree, attempting to elevate extremist candidates who they think will be easy to defeat in midterms in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Amy Chang Chien
title: Chinese military drills circling Taiwan set up a potential standoff.
description: China’s plans to conduct live-fire drills into Taiwan’s territorial seas could mark a new stage of brinkmanship.
content: Although much attention has been on Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan, the real potential for a military showdown comes now that she has left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Bid to Cap Russian Oil Prices Draws Skepticism Over Enforcement
description: The maritime insurance industry says policing oil transactions is not workable, raising questions about enforcement of a buyers’ cartel.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s push to form an international buyers’ cartel to cap the price of Russian oil is facing resistance amid private sector concerns that it cannot be reliably enforced, posing a challenge for the U.S.-led effort to drain President Vladimir V. Putin’s war chest and stabilize global energy prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Vin Scully Was Los Angeles
description: In a town synonymous with fleeting fame, Scully was the one thing that always seemed to endure. His voice, “like a gentle hand,” still resonates.
content: He was Venice Beach, Pink’s hot-dog stand and the Hollywood Bowl all rolled into one. He was Los Angeles, the sound of summer, the poet laureate of the Dodgers — Brooklyn and Los Angeles — for 67 seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Eric Schmitt defeats Eric Greitens to win Missouri’s G.O.P. Senate primary.
description: The victory by Mr. Schmitt, the state attorney general, was a relief for Republicans who wanted to stop Mr. Greitens, the scandal-plagued former governor, from securing the nomination.
content: Eric Schmitt, the Missouri attorney general, easily captured the Republican nomination for an open Senate seat on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. His decisive victory derailed the political comeback of former Gov. Eric Greitens, whose campaign had been clouded by allegations of domestic abuse, infidelity and corruption.
source.name: The New York Times
